p: The seroprevalence of RVFV varied geographically and temporally in livestock, wildlife and humans. These trends are summarised in Figs 4 and 5, while the full data are presented in S2 Table. Median RVFV seroprevalence was 12.9% in sheep (range 0–100%), 12.6% in cattle (range 0–100%); 11.3% in wildlife (range 0–87.5%), 10.1% in goats (range 0–69.6%); 8.8% in camels (range 0–57.1%) and 5.9% in humans (range 0–81.0%). The highest RVFV seroprevalence in livestock was identified in sheep and cattle in Egypt during an epizootic in 1997, where 100% of samples were seropositive (93 cattle and 57 sheep) ( S2 Table) [ 38]. RVFV seroprevalence was significantly higher during outbreak periods compared to IEPs in goats (Wilcox rank sum test, outbreak median = 50%, IEP median = 9.40%, p = 0.001) and sheep (Wilcox rank sum test, outbreak median = 34.8%, IEP median = 12.9%, p = 0.01) but not in cattle, camels or humans ( Fig 5).
